{{DISPLAYTITLE:eTBLAST}} {{COI|date=August 2011}} '''eTBLAST''' is a now-defunct free text similarity service [[search engine]] which offered access to the [[MEDLINE]] database, the [[National Institutes of Health]] (NIH) [[Computer Retrieval of Information on Scientific Projects|CRISP]] database, the [[Institute of Physics]] (IOP) database, [[Wikipedia]], [[arXiv]], the [[NASA]] technical reports database, Virginia Tech class descriptions and a variety of databases of clinical interest. It is continuously expanding with additional text-based databases. eTBLAST searched citation databases<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1093/bioinformatics/btl388 |title=Text similarity: An alternative way to search MEDLINE |year=2006 |last1=Lewis |first1=J |last2=Ossowski |first2=S |last3=Hicks |first3=J |last4=Errami |first4=M |last5=Garner |first5=HR |journal=Bioinformatics |volume=22 |issue=18 |pages=2298–304 |pmid=16926219 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1109/MEMB.2004.1378640 |title=Text comparison based on dynamic programming |year=2004 |last1=Pertsemlidis |first1=A |last2=Garner |first2=HR |journal=IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Magazine |volume=23 |issue=6 |pages=66–71 |pmid=15688594 }}</ref> and databases containing full text,<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0012704 |title=Systematic Characterizations of Text Similarity in Full Text Biomedical Publications |year=2010 |editor1-last=Curioso |editor1-first=Walter H |last1=Sun |first1=Z |last2=Errami |first2=M |last3=Long |first3=T |last4=Renard |first4=C |last5=Choradia |first5=N |last6=Garner |first6=H |journal=PLoS ONE |volume=5 |issue=9 |pages=e12704 |pmid=20856807 |pmc=2939881 |bibcode=2010PLoSO...512704S }}</ref> such as [[PUBMED]]. The eTBLAST server compared a user's natural text query to target databases using a hybrid search algorithm consisting of a low-sensitivity weighted keyword-based first pass followed by a novel sentence-alignment based second pass. eTBLAST was a web-based service of The Innovation Laboratory at the [[Virginia Bioinformatics Institute]].
eTBLAST, as a text similarity engine, made possible a large study of duplicate publications and potential plagiarisms in the biomedical literature. Thousands of random samples of Medline abstracts were submitted to eTBLAST, and those with the highest similarity were studied and entered into an on-line database. This work revealed several trends, including an increasing rate of duplication in the biomedical literature, as reported in the journals ''[[Bioinformatics (journal)|Bioinformatics]]'',<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1093/bioinformatics/btm574 |title=Deja vu a study of duplicate citations in Medline |year=2007 |last1=Errami |first1=M |last2=Hicks |first2=JM |last3=Fisher |first3=W |last4=Trusty |first4=D |last5=Wren |first5=JD |last6=Long |first6=TC |last7=Garner |first7=HR |journal=Bioinformatics |volume=24 |issue=2 |pages=243–9 |pmid=18056062 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1093/bioinformatics/btq146 |title=Identifying duplicate content using statistically improbable phrases |year=2010 |last1=Errami |first1=M |last2=Sun |first2=Z |last3=George |first3=AC |last4=Long |first4=TC |last5=Skinner |first5=MA |last6=Wren |first6=JD |last7=Garner |first7=HR |journal=Bioinformatics |volume=26 |issue=11 |pages=1453–7 |pmid=20472545 |pmc=2872002 }}</ref> ''[[Anaesthesia and Intensive Care]]'',<ref>{{cite journal |pmid=18853580 |year=2008 |last1=Loadsman |first1=JA |last2=Garner |first2=HR |last3=Drummond |first3=GB |title=Towards the elimination of duplication in ''Anaesthesia and Intensive Care'' |volume=36 |issue=5 |pages=643–5 |journal=Anaesthesia and Intensive Care |url=http://www.aaic.net.au/document/?D=20080552 }}</ref> ''[[Clinical Chemistry (journal)|Clinical Chemistry]]'',<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1373/clinchem.2009.130468 |title=Quaere Verum |year=2010 |last1=George |first1=AC |last2=Long |first2=TC |last3=Garner |first3=HR |journal=Clinical Chemistry |volume=56 |issue=4 |pages=673–4 |pmid=20093558 }}</ref> ''[[Urologic Oncology]]'',<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.urolonc.2010.09.016 |title=Combating unethical publications with plagiarism detection services |year=2011 |last1=Garner |first1=HR |journal=Urologic Oncology |volume=29 |pages=95–9 |pmid= 21194644 |pmc=3035174}}</ref> ''[[Nature (journal)|Nature]]'',<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1038/451397a |title=A tale of two citations |year=2008 |last1=Errami |first1=M |last2=Garner |first2=H |journal=Nature |volume=451 |issue=7177 |pages=397–9 |pmid=18216832 |bibcode=2008Natur.451..397E }}</ref> and ''[[Science (journal)|Science]]''.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1126/science.1167408 |title=Responding to Possible Plagiarism |year=2009 |last1=Long |first1=TC |last2=Errami |first2=M |last3=George |first3=AC |last4=Sun |first4=Z |last5=Garner |first5=HR |journal=Science |volume=323 |issue=5919 |pages=1293–4 |pmid=19265004 }}</ref>
The system is now called "HelioBLAST" [http://helioblast.heliotext.com/] and is offered, still free of charge, by Harold "Skip" Garner through his company HelioText [http://www.heliotext.com/].
==See also== *[[BLAST]] (Basic Local Alignment Search Tool) *[[Natural language processing]] *[[Medical literature retrieval]]

{{Virginia Tech}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Etblast}} [[Category:Virginia Tech]] [[Category:Bioinformatics software]] [[Category:National Institutes of Health]] [[Category:Medical search engines]] [[Category:Natural language processing]] [[Category:Bibliographic databases and indexes]] [[Category:Plagiarism detectors]]

In [[philosophy]] and [[rhetoric]], '''eristic''' (from ''[[Eris (mythology)|Eris]]'', the ancient Greek [[goddess]] of chaos, strife, and discord) refers to [[argument]] that aims to successfully dispute another's argument, rather than searching for [[truth]]. According to T.H. Irwin, "It is characteristic of the eristic to think of some arguments as a way of defeating the other side, by showing that an opponent must assent to the negation of what he initially took himself to believe."<ref>Irwin, T.H. "Plato's Objection to the Sophists." The Greek World. London: Routledge, 1995. P. 585. Print.</ref> Eristic is arguing for the sake of conflict, as opposed to resolving conflict.<ref>H.D. Rankin (1983). Sophists, Socratics and Cynics. Pp. 233–237.</ref>
==Use in education== Eristic was a type of "question-and-answer"<ref>Alexander Nehamas. "Eristic, Antilogic, Sophistic, Dialectic: Plato's Demarcation of Philosophy from Sophistry". (page 6)</ref> teaching method popularized by the [[Sophism|Sophists]], such as [[Euthydemus (Socratic literature)|Euthydemos]] and [[Dionysodoros]]. Students learned eristic arguments to "refute their opponent, no matter whether he [said] yes or no in answer to their initial question".<ref>Irwin, T.H. "Plato's Objection to the Sophists." The Greek World. London: Routledge, 1995. 583. Print.</ref>
[[Plato]] contrasted this type of argument with [[dialectic]] and other more [[reason]]able and [[logic]]al methods (e.g., at [[The Republic (Plato)|''Republic'']] 454a). In the dialogue [[Euthydemus (dialogue)|''Euthydemus'']], Plato satirizes eristic. It is more than persuasion, and it is more than discourse. It is a combination that wins an argument without regard to truth. Plato believed that the eristic style "did not constitute a method of argument" because to argue eristically is to consciously use fallacious arguments, which therefore weakens one's position.<ref>Alexander Nehamas. "Eristic, Antilogic, Sophistic, Dialectic: Plato's Demarcation of Philosophy from Sophistry". (page 7).</ref>
Unlike Plato, [[Isocrates]] (often considered a Sophist) did not distinguish eristic from dialectic.<ref>http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus:text:1999.01.0168:book=5:section=454a</ref> He held that both lacked a "'useful application' ... that created responsible citizens",<ref>Marsh, Charles. Classical rhetoric and modern public relations: an Isocratean model. New York: Routledge, 2013. P. 121.</ref> which unscrupulous teachers used for "enriching themselves at the expense of the youth."<ref>http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus:text:1999.01.0144:speech=15:section=45</ref>
==Philosophical eristic== [[Schopenhauer]] considers that only logic pursues truth. For him, [[dialectic]], [[sophistry]] and eristic have no objective truth in view, but only the appearance of it, and pay no regard to truth itself because it aims at victory. He names these three last methods as "eristic dialectic (contentious argument)."<ref>[http://coolhaus.de/art-of-controversy/eristii.htm Controversial Dialectic] on CoolHaus.de accessed at January 19, 2008</ref>
According to [[Schopenhauer]], [[The Art of Being Right|''Eristic Dialectic'']] is mainly concerned to tabulate and analyze dishonest stratagems,<ref>In his ''Dialectica Eristica'' Schopenhauer presents 38 eristic stratagems</ref> so that they may at once be recognized and defeated, in order to continue with a productive dialectic debate. It is for this very reason that Eristic Dialectic must admittedly take victory, and not objective truth, for its selfish aim and purpose.
==Argumentation theory== [[Argumentation theory]] is a field of study that asks critical questions about eristic arguments and the other types of dialogue.
==See also== *''[[The Art of Being Right]]'' *[[Informal fallacy|Logical fallacy]] *[[Eris (mythology)]]
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==References== * Schopenhauer, Arthur. ''Eristische Dialektik'', 1830. * [http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/191570/eristic Encyclopædia Britannica defines ''eristic'']
==External links== * Arthur Schopenhauer's ''Eristische Dialektik'': ** [http://coolhaus.de/art-of-controversy/ German and English version of ''Eristische Dialektik''] ** [http://gutenberg.spiegel.de/?id=5&xid=2517&kapitel=1 German version of ''Eristische Dialektik''] {{authority control}} [[Category:Arguments]] [[Category:Rhetoric]] [[Category:Epistemology]]

{{refimprove|date=March 2014}} [[File:Rector Vallfogona Poesia.JPG|thumb|180px|Poem of the '''Vallfogona Rector''' in a street in [[Vallfogona de Riucorb]]]] '''Francesc Vicent Garcia i Torres''' ({{IPA-ca|fɾənˈsɛzɡ biˈsɛŋ ɡəɾˈsi.ə}}) was an early modern [[Spanish people|Spanish]] poet known by the pseudonym of the '''Vallfogona Rector'''. He was born in [[Tortosa]] in the [[Baix Ebre]] [[comarca]] around 1582 and died in [[Vallfogona de Riucorb]] ([[Conca de Barberà]]) in 1623. In 1605 he was ordained in [[Vic]].
==Early life== Vicent Garcia completed his religious studies in Barcelona. In Vic, where he was ordained, he was the secretary to Bishop Francis Robust. In 1607, Garcia was appointed to the Vallfogona Riucorb rectory, where he remained until 1621. This spell at Vallfogona was followed by appointment to the post of secretary of the Bishop of [[Girona]], Peter Moncada. A year after taking up this post, Garcia obtained a doctorate in theology from the College of St. George and St. Matthias in [[Tortosa]]. Vallfogona Riucorb died on September 2, 1623. Barcelona was a central place in Garcia's life. It was a city he visited frequently. In Barcelona, Garcia moved in the literary circle that met Bishop Juan de Moncada in his palace.<ref name="Vicent Garcia">{{cite web|title=Vicent Garcia|url=http://www.escriptors.cat/autors/garciafv/pagina.php?id_sec=1089|accessdate=11 November 2013}}</ref>
==Legacy== He cultivated an artful and elegant verse in sonnets and [[décima]] form, and also wrote violent [[satire]] and obscene or [[grotesque]] compositions. His style was imitated by many Catalan authors of the 18th century, a phenomenon known as "vallfogonisme." In 1703 a portion of his work was published. The 1770 edition was banned by the [[Inquisition]]. In 1988 Albert Rossich included some of his poems in an [https://www.amazon.com/dp/8485704665/ anthology] of erotic and pornographic Catalan poetry from the 17th century.
==Rumors== Vicent Garcia was subject to numerous rumors. One of them was that he visited Madrid in 1622 at the request of King [[Philip IV of Spain|Philip IV]]. Another baseless belief was that he had a friendship with [[Lope de Vega]]. Perhaps the most absurd was the story of his alleged poisoning by [[Zaragoza]] courtiers. His literary stature, however, was unquestionable. He is widely accepted as the first great Catalan writer. His works were seminal, creating a literary school that lasted well into the nineteenth century.<ref name="Vicent Garcia" />
==Style== Garcia's poetry resembled that of Spanish contemporary poets, especially in terms of the formality and theme. His use of language was particularly unique. He had a predilection for an elegant form of language, and his writings were always laced with irony and literary subjects. It was this characteristic in his work that drew comparisons with [[Francisco de Quevedo|Quevedo]]. Some of Garcia best-known poems are ''A Lady in A beautiful Black Hair'', ''Epitaph On the Grave Of a Heavy Drinker'', and the sonnet ''Time''. As the titles suggest, Garcia was a versatile poet, writing on diverse topics. He was also a playwright, and wrote a play, ''Comedy in Santa Barbara'', to mark the occasion of the inauguration of the chapel of Santa Barbara Vallfogona in 1617.<ref name="Vicent Garcia" />
[[File:Rector de Vallfogona (gravat difós l'any 1840).jpg|thumb|Francesc Vicent Garcia i Torres.]] [[File:Poesías jocosas y serias del célebre Dr. Vicens García (1820).djvu|thumb|Cover of Francesc Vicent Garcia i Torres's book]] [[File:Poesías jocosas y serias-soneto I.png|thumb|right|A sonnet by Francesc Vicent Garcia i Torres]]

{{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox writer | name = G.S. Amur | image = | caption = | pseudonym = | birth_name = Gururaja ShyamacharyaAmur | spouse = Shantha Anur | relatives = K. S. Amur | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1925|5|8}} | birth_place = Bommanahalli, [[Dharwad District]], Karnataka state, India | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = Writer
professor | nationality = Indian | period = | genre = [[Literary Criticism]] | subject = | movement = | awards = Pampa award,
Sahitya Akademi Award,
Bendre Award,
Rajyotsava Award,
State award | influences = | influenced = | language = [[Kannada]],
English,
[[Sanskrit]],
[[Marathi language|Marathi]] | website = }} '''Gururaja Shyamacharya Amur''' ([[Kannada script|Kannada]]: ಜಿ. ಎಸ್. ಆಮೂರ; born 8 May 1925), a professor of literature, is a contemporary writer and critic in the [[Kannada]] and English languages. He is a recipient of many prestigious awards including the Central Sahitya Akademi Award instituted by the Government of India. Amur is the older brother of mathematician [[K. S. Amur]]. == Career== Amur was born in Bommanahalli village in the [[Dharwad]] district. He obtained his [[Master of Arts]] degree in English from the [[University of Mumbai]] and his PhD in English from the [[Karnatak University]], [[Dharwar]]. His thesis was titled [http://www.worldcatlibraries.org/wcpa/top3mset/14982528 ''The Concept of Comedy'']. After his M.A., Amur worked as a Professor of English at the [[Karnatak University]], [[Dharwad]] and [[Marathwada University]] in [[Aurangabad, Maharashtra|Aurangabad]] before he visited the [[University of California at Santa Barbara]] and [[Yale University]] as a Senior [[Fulbright]] scholar in 1972 and 1973. He is married to Shanta Amur and currently resides in Dharwad. == Literary work== ===Awards=== * [[Masti Award]] in 2010{{cite news|url=http://www.deccanherald.com/content/61980/masti-award-g-s-amur.html|title=' Masti award for G S Amur'|work=Online webpage of Deccan Herald|publisher=Deccan Herald|accessdate=17 January 2011|location=Bangalore,India|date=3 April 2010}} * [[Adikavi Pampa|Pampa Award]] in 2006{{cite news|url=http://www.hindu.com/2007/03/27/stories/2007032706570400.htm|title= ' G.S. Amur, Lalitha Naik among those chosen for State awards'|work=Online webpage of The Hindu|publisher=The Hindu|accessdate=16 January 2008|location=Chennai, India|date=27 March 2007}} * [[D. R. Bendre|Da. Ra. Bendre Award]] in 2005{{cite news|url=http://www.hindu.com/2006/02/01/stories/2006020108160300.htm|title= ' G.S. Amur receives Bendre Award'|work=Online webpage of The Hindu|publisher=The Hindu|accessdate=16 January 2008|location=Chennai, India|date=1 February 2006}} * [[Rajyotsava Award]] in 2000{{cite web|url=http://www.hinduonnet.com/2000/10/31/stories/04312109.htm|title= '51 chosen for Rajyotsava award: Amur, Sudha, Simha among recipients'|work=Online webpage of The Hindu|publisher=The Hindu|accessdate=16 January 2008}} * [[Sahitya Akademi Award]] in 1996{{cite web|url=http://www.sahitya-akademi.org/sahitya-akademi/awa10307.htm#kannada |title='Awards and Fellowships' |work=Online webpage of Sahitya Akademi |publisher=Sahitya Akademi |accessdate=16 January 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071211010650/http://www.sahitya-akademi.org/sahitya-akademi/awa10307.htm |archivedate=11 December 2007 }} * [[Bharatiya Bhasha Parishad Award]] in 1993, 1994 * ''Hons'' S.S. Malwad Prashasti in 1988 * Karnataka [[Sahitya Akademi Award|Sahitya Akademi]] in 1988 == Bibliography == === Books === ==== Kannada ==== * ''Ninda Hejje'' (2004) * ''Bendre Kaavya'' (2003) * ''Kannada Kathana Sahitya: Sanna Kathe'' (2003) *''Seemollanghana'' (2002) *''Kathanashastra'' (2001) *''Shantinath Desai'' (2000) *''Amrutavaahini'' (2000) *''Bendrekaavyada Pratimaaloka'' (2000) *''Dattatreya Ramachandra Bendre'' (2000) *''Kaadambariya Swaroopa'' (1999) *''Viraata Purusha: Shriranga Saraswata Sameekshe'' (1998) *''Saatvika Patha'' (1995) *''Kannada Kathana Sahitya: Kaadambari'' (1994) *''Comedy'' (1993) *''Vyavasaaya'' (1992) *''Bhuvanada Bhagya'' (1991) *''Arthaloka'' (1988) *''A.N. Krishnarayaru'' (1987) *''Kannada Kaadambariya Belevanige'' (1983) ==== English ==== *''Dattatreya Ramachandra Bendre'' (1994) *''Creations & Transcreations'' (1992) *''Forbidden Fruit, Views on Indo-Anglian Fiction'' (1992) *''A.N. Krishnarao'' (1987) *''Colonial Consciousness in Commonwealth Literature'' (1984) *''Essays on Comparative Literature and Linguistics'' (1984) *''Images and Impressions: Essays Mainly on Contemporary Indian Literature'' (1979) *''The Concept of Comedy: A Re-statement'' (1963) === Anthologies === '''Kannada''' *''Koralu Kolalu: Collection of critical articles on modern kannada poetry'' (2006) *''Anthology of Selected Plays of Sriranga'' (2005) *''Swatantryottara Sannakathegalu (2004) *''Avala Kathegalu'' (1999) *''Selected Kannada Short Stories'' (1993) === Essays === '''English''' * ''The River, the Lotus Pond and the Ruined Temple: An Essay on Symbolism in RK Narayan's Novels'' (1985) * ''Philip Roth's My Life as a Man: Portrait of the Artist as a Trapped Husband'' (1984) * ''The Beautiful and the Necessary: A Note on Emerson's Idea of Form'' (1983) * ''Marriage as Symbolic Strategy in Seeta, Esmond in India and The Serpent and the Rope'' (1981) * ''Theme, Structure, and Symbol in The Catcher in the Rye'' (1969) * ''Self-Recognition in The Serpent and The Rope'' * ''A Saint for Malgudi: A New Look at R.K. Narayan’s The Guide'' * ''Hellenic Heroines and Sexless Angels: Images of Women in Forster's Novels'' == References == {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Amur, G. S.}} [[Category:1925 births]] [[Category:Writers from Karnataka]] [[Category:Kannada-language writers]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Dharwad district]] [[Category:Recipients of the Sahitya Akademi Award in Kannada]] [[Category:Karnatak University alumni]] [[Category:20th-century Indian essayists]] [[Category:Indian male essayists]] [[Category:Indian literary critics]] [[Category:English-language writers from India]] [[Category:20th-century Indian poets]] [[Category:20th-century Indian dramatists and playwrights]] [[Category:20th-century Indian male writers]]

{{Infobox language family |name=Greater Siangic |acceptance=proposed |region=[[Arunachal Pradesh]] |familycolor=Sino-Tibetan |family=possibly [[Sino-Tibetan languages|Sino-Tibetan]] or an independent family |child1=[[Siangic languages|Siangic]] |child2=[[Digaro languages|Digaro]] |child3=[[Tani languages|Tani]] |glotto2=macr1268 |glottorefname2=Macro-Tani |glotto3=mish1241 |glottorefname3=Mishmic [Digaro] }} '''Greater Siangic''' is a language grouping proposed by [[Roger Blench]] (2014). It includes the ''[[Siangic languages]]'', ''[[Digaro languages]]'' ([[Idu Mishmi language|Idu Mishmi]] and [[Taraon language|Taraon]]) and ''Pre-[[Tani languages|Tani]]'', the hypothetical [[stratum (linguistics)|substrate]] language branch of Tani before it became relexified by Sino-Tibetan. Blench (2014) argues that Greater Siangic is an independent language family that has undergone areal influences from [[Sino-Tibetan languages]], and is not a branch of the Sino-Tibetan language family itself.
==Languages== ;Greater Siangic *Pre-[[Tani languages|Tani]] *[[Idu Mishmi language|Idu]]-[[Taraon language|Taraon]] *[[Siangic languages|Siangic]] **[[Koro language (India)|Koro]] **[[Milang language|Milang]]
==References== {{reflist}} * Blench, Roger (2014). ''[https://www.academia.edu/8136744/Fallen_leaves_blow_away_a_neo-Hammarstromian_approach_to_Sino-Tibetan_classification Fallen leaves blow away: a neo-Hammarstromian approach to Sino-Tibetan classification]''. Presentation given at the University of New England, Armidale, 6 September 2014. * Post, Mark W. and Roger Blench (2011). "[https://jamescook.academia.edu/MarkWPost/Talks/33486/Siangic_A_new_language_phylum_in_North_East_India Siangic: A new language phylum in North East India]", ''6th International Conference of the North East India Linguistics Society'', Tezpur University, Assam, India, Jan 31 – Feb 2.
{{Language families}} {{ST branches}}
[[Category:Greater Siangic languages| ]] [[Category:Languages of India]] [[Category:Proposed language families]]

'''John Rowlands''' (August 14, 1938 – 23 February 2015)<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-31588188 "Welsh author John Rowlands dies, 76", ''BBC News'', 23 February 2015]</ref><ref>[http://www.themodernnovel.org/europe/w-europe/wales/rowlands/ John Rowlands, ''TheModernNovel.org'']. Retrieved 23 February 2015</ref> was a [[Welsh language]] author of several novels including ''Lle bo'r gwenyn'' ("Where Bees May Be", 1960), and a Professor of [[Welsh-language literature|Welsh literature]].
==Biography== Born in [[Trawsfynydd]], [[Merionethshire]], Rowlands graduated in Welsh from [[Bangor University]] in 1959 and went on to lecture at Abertawe/Swansea, Coleg y Drindod, [[Caerfyrddin]], [[Llanbedr Pont Steffan]] and [[Aberystwyth]]. He retired in 2003 but remained active as an editor, critic and judge. In retirement he worked on creative writing courses at Bangor.
His academic work included editing a major literary series ''Y Meddwl a'r Dychymyg Cymreig'' and numerous volumes and papers. He was one of the most prolific judges in the [[Eisteddfod]] literary competitions and was probably the foremost critic in Welsh on Welsh. He also contributed a regular column to the magazine [[Barn (Welsh magazine)|Barn]] and was a wine and restaurant critic.
==Works==
===Novels=== *''Lle bo'r Gwenyn'' (1960) *''Yn ôl i'w Teyrnasoedd'' (1963) *''Ienctid yw 'mhechod (1965) *''Llawer Is na'r Angylion'' (1968) *''Bydded Tywyllwch'' (1969) *''Arch ym Mhrâg'' (1972) *''Tician Tician'' (1978)
===Academic books=== *''Priodas Waed'', translation of 'Bodas de Sangre' by Lorca (with R Bryn Williams) (1977) *Writers of Wales, T Rowland Hughes (1975) *Profiles (with G Jones) (1981) *Cnoi Cil ar Lenyddiaeth (1989) *Ysgrifau ar y Nofel (1992) *Y Meddwl a'r Dychymyg Cymreig - series editor
==References== {{Reflist}} ''Companion to Welsh Literature'' (Cydymaith i Lenyddiaeth Cymru). ed. Meic Stephens. University of Wales Press, Cardiff. 1986.
{{Authority control}}
